div.h4: Distance Learning Begins on Monday, April 13
div.p: Hello Reynolds Families!

Distance Learning For All is ready for our students! Please visit the Distance Learning page or your school website for the information you’ll need to begin digital learning on Monday. The Distance Learning page will have all the information students need to log in and work directly with their teacher.
If you need to request a device, get help logging in to Schoology, or have other questions, please visit our Let’s Talk page to submit a help ticket.

Thank you,
Reynolds School District
div.h4: Letter from the Superintendent of Schools 4/8/2020
div.p: April 8, 2020
Dear Reynolds School District Families,

Today we learned our students will not be returning to school campuses this school year, according to an executive order from Governor Kate Brown. The Governor extended the closure of school buildings through the rest of this academic year in an effort to slow the spread of COVID-19.

Reynolds School District will continue to deliver meaningful experiences for students for the duration of our academic year through Distance Learning. Your student’s teachers have been working to connect with you and your student this week. If you are experiencing challenges receiving communication from your teachers, your principals are ready to help solve those challenges. Please contact your principal via email which can be found on each school’s website or you can submit an inquiry through our Let’s Talk online system. We are also working to schedule the checkout of technology devices to families who may not have any available device at home to facilitate Distance Learning. If your family does not have an available device, please visit the district’s website for more information.

Distance Learning for All officially begins on Monday, April 13, 2020. This means your student will begin working with their teacher to continue their learning while at home starting next week and we look forward to reconnecting! Our teachers and support staff are committed to your child’s education and are excited to be learning new ways of educating our students over the next few months. We will continue to keep you informed as we navigate this path.

The Oregon Department of Education also announced today a plan for senior graduation requirements. We are currently reviewing the guidance but want to let you know that this will not impact our seniors’ ability to graduate on time. We are committed to ensuring every senior has the resources needed to graduate, and we will be reaching out to each senior individually to determine their specific path to graduation this year.

This extended closure also means the loss of traditional celebrations and ceremonies that students may have been looking forward to, such as dances, sporting events, field trips, performances, graduations, and award ceremonies. Our hearts are with every student in realizing these losses. Please know that we are actively looking for ways to honor our students, specifically our graduates, while still maintaining social distancing guidelines and closures. We will be engaging with students and families soon to gather feedback and ideas on how these milestones might be accomplished, and how we can support these special celebrations in new and unique ways.

We know many of our families are experiencing challenges and hardships during this unprecedented time. Every day seems to bring a new normal and those changes can be stressful and difficult for all. We care deeply about the well-being of each and every Reynolds student and their family.

I know our families are impacted by food, housing, and financial insecurities at this time. We are here to help you navigate through these difficult times. We will continue to offer breakfast and lunch distribution for students at various school sites during the school week while closed. Specific information can be found on our websites or Facebook. We also have information about food pantries, medical access, housing help, and mental health resources available on our website. Please reach out to your student’s teacher, the school principal, or the District Office if you are in need of help accessing important resources for the health and safety of your family.

This global pandemic is something we have never experienced before, but we will survive. In coming together as a community, we will weather this storm with strength and grace. I look forward to the day I have the honor of welcoming you back through the doors of our schools once again.
Together… We are Reynolds!

Warm regards,
Dr. Danna Diaz
Superintendent of Schools
div.h4: Letter from the Superintendent of Schools 4/1/2020
div.p: April 1, 2020
Dear Reynolds School District Families,

Late Monday night we received new guidance from the Oregon Department of Education (ODE) about moving from the original mandate of providing “Supplemental Education and Learning Supports” to delivering “Distance Learning for All.”

This shift means your students will be learning new material and receiving assessments and credit for their work remotely. This could also signal the possibility of schools being closed for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year. We have not yet been informed of this but will make you aware if we receive that order in the future

The possibility of our schools not reopening for the rest of this school year weighs heavily on our hearts and is difficult to comprehend. The implications will take time for everyone to fully process. Regardless, we are looking forward to engaging your students in remote learning opportunities beginning Monday, April 6, 2020.

Reynolds School District leadership is committed to analyzing, interpreting, and making plans for the shift as quickly as possible over the next few days. Fortunately, we have already started this work with plans in place for our teachers to start reaching out to students and families this week. With news of this updated guidance from ODE, we believe Reynolds School District is well positioned to deliver on this new direction.

ODE has identified April 13th as the required date for distance learning for all to begin and we will transition our community into a new way of teaching and learning leading up to that date. It is an opportunity for us to practice and try new things, figure out what works, and learn what we can do better through this time. Along the way, we will be sharing with you new developments, directions, and supports, and we greatly appreciate your patience and flexibility during this time.

p.strong: What exactly will this look like for your students starting this week?

div.p: Teachers and staff were officially working remotely on Monday, and they are actively planning and preparing educational materials to engage in learning with your students starting on Monday, April 6th. Here is what you can do to prepare your student:

ul.li: Please look for an email from your principal and/or teacher(s) by the end of the day Friday, April 3rd (if not sooner) with details on how your student can engage with their teachers and school.
Through the rest of this week, teachers and support staff will begin engaging with students, making connections, and transitioning to distance learning opportunities.

From April 6th through 10th, teachers will be engaging students in digital learning opportunities to work independently and collaboratively with their teacher. This may include teachers interacting with students remotely at scheduled times during the school day.
The daily schedule will be flexible enough to accommodate variations between teachers, the availability of students, and families’ demands of working from home.

div.p: To make this work, we hope you are able to provide access for your student to a digital device in your home. If you do not have a device at home (laptop, Chromebook, iPad, etc.), please let your student’s teacher know when they reach out to you. We are currently gathering information on the needs of our families to begin checking out a device to each family that does not have one in the home. Please stay tuned for more information about this topic.

ul.li: If your student is a middle or high school student and did not check out a device when they were issued previously, please use the Let’s Talk feature from your phone or device on the district website to submit the student name, school name, and grade level to schedule a check-out with the technology department.

If your student is a middle or high school student and left their assigned device in the school prior to closure, please here to submit the student name, school name and location in the school of the device to schedule a pick up from the technology department.
If you have any problems or concerns please let your student’s teacher or principal know, or use our Let’s Talk platform, which can be found at https://www.reynolds.k12.or.us/district/lets-talk.

div.p: I am confident in the talent and skills of our leaders, teachers, support staff, and families in ensuring our students’ continued education during this time. I look forward to learning along with you as we navigate these new waters.
Together... “We are Reynolds!”

Sincerely,
Dr. Danna Diaz, Superintendent of Schools
Dear Reynolds School District Students, Parents, and Community,

We are truly in unprecedented times as a community and I would like to thank each of you for the care and compassion you are showing one another as we all learn to navigate our circumstances. As this worldwide pandemic increases and begins to impact the health of our own community, my deepest condolences go out to our students, families, and school staff who may experience illness of their own or with family members. The Reynolds community is strong, and we will be here for one another during difficult times.

As our lives have experienced this upheaval, there are many questions we are all facing. I am hopeful to answer some of your questions regarding how our district is responding to this crisis today and will continue to offer information as we have it.

I would like to ensure you that we will continue to serve meals to our students and families during the school closure. The first week we were closed (March 16-20), our incredible Nutrition Services and other support staff and volunteers distributed over 20,000 breakfast and lunch meals!

We will start our meal distribution again on Monday, March 30, 2020 and expand distribution sites during the week. You can drive up or walk up to receive a bagged breakfast and lunch for your students Monday through Friday from 11:30am to 1:00pm at the following sites. We will have social distancing measures in place to protect you, your children, and our staff during meal distributions. Thank you for helping us to keep everyone safe!

div.p: Reynolds School District is committed to serving our students' learning while schools are closed. Currently, you can find Learning Resources for students across all grades on our website. You can access that site here: https://www.reynolds.k12.or.us/district/learning-resources The resources listed on this page will be updated again on Monday, March 30th.

Beginning next week, teachers will be creating new supplemental educational and learning supports for students in their individual classes. School staff will also check in with families and students by phone, email, and the Remind app. By April 3rd, you will receive the information you need for all students to access their own teacher’s online resources and those resources will be available beginning April 6, 2020. We look forward to being able to offer more opportunities for your students to continue learning and we appreciate your patience as we create these new ways to connect with you and your children.

This time of uncertainty is more pronounced with our graduating Seniors. They are understandably confused, worried, disappointed, and upset that their final months of school have been disrupted. I want you to know that our teachers, administrators, and the entire Reynolds School District share these concerns. We are closely monitoring direction from the state and will let students and families know as soon as any guidance is received. Teachers will be contacting Seniors beginning next week to determine next steps on an individual basis.

We also know that students and families are worried about graduation ceremonies and accompanying activities. While we can’t promise that we will be able to have the traditional ceremony we all look forward to, we are working hard to ensure that students and families have a meaningful and memorable graduation experience this spring. We will continue to keep you updated as we move forward.

My wish is for you and your family to remain safe and healthy. Please follow Governor Brown’s directive to “Stay Home. Save Lives.” Stay home as much as possible, stay six feet away from others when you are out, only venture out for essentials, and help those around you that might not be able to leave their home to get groceries. Take this opportunity to work one-on-one with your students with the learning resources available now and encourage interaction with their teachers starting next week.
If we all pull together as a community, we can weather this storm. Together… “We are Reynolds!”
Dr. Danna Diaz, Superintendent of Schools

Dear Reynolds Families and Staff,

Governor Kate Brown signed an executive order this afternoon mandating that all public schools in Oregon are to remain closed to students through April 28, 2020 to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus COVID-19.

We understand that this is a trying time and that the closure of our schools presents challenges to all. Please know that we are doing everything in our power to find and offer resources for our families and staff. Here is what we know now and what you can expect from us until we learn more:

ul.li:
We will continue to provide meals to children 18 and under during the closure. We are currently offering curbside meals this week Wednesday (3/18/2020) through Friday (3/20/2020) from 11:30am to 1:00pm at HB Lee Middle School, Reynolds Middle School, Walt Morey Middle School, and Reynolds High School.
As previously planned, we will not be delivering meals during Spring Break week (3/23-3/27/2020). More information on where and when you can access meals after Spring Break week will be coming soon.​

We will provide information to our families to access important resources. We know our families will be struggling with the closures of schools and other businesses and may need to access help quickly. We will keep you informed of various ways to access necessary support services. In the meantime, please visit 211info.org for immediate needs.

We will review options for remote or supplemental learning opportunities for our students. While we cannot guarantee at this time that we can provide this type of learning during the closure, please know that we are actively researching ways for our students to stay engaged. We will continue to keep you informed. In the meantime, we will be sending you links to education resources you can use to actively work with your children while they are home. This information will be coming tomorrow.

We will continue to ask our students, families, and staff to understand the importance of this national health emergency by practicing social distancing measures of not gathering with more than 10 people, consistent hand washing, avoiding people who are sick, and covering coughs and sneezes. Any staff listed as essential and working in our schools or offices to support necessary functions are asked to stay home if ill, if they are in an at-risk category, or have a member of their household in an at-risk category.

div.p: We will continue to keep you updated as we have more information. By each doing our part, we can pull through these difficult times. We appreciate your patience, kindness, and compassion in the coming days. Remember… Together, we are Reynolds!

Esta tarde, la gobernadora Kate Brown, firmó una orden ejecutiva que exige que todas las escuelas públicas de Oregón permanezcan cerradas para los estudiantes hasta el 28 de abril de 2020 para evitar la propagación del nuevo coronavirus COVID-19.

Entendemos que este es un momento difícil y que el cierre de nuestras escuelas presenta desafíos para todos. Tenga en cuenta que estamos haciendo todo lo que está a nuestro alcance para encontrar y ofrecer recursos para nuestras familias y el personal. Esto es lo que sabemos ahora y lo que puede esperar de nosotros hasta que sepamos más:

ul.li:
Continuaremos brindando comidas a niños menores de 18 años durante el cierre. Actualmente ofrecemos comidas en la acera esta semana del miércoles 18 de marzo al viernes 20 de marzo de 2020 de 11:30 a.m. a 1:00 p.m. en las escuelas secundarias HB Lee, Reynolds Midle, Walt Morey y Reynolds High School.
Como se planificó previamente, no entregaremos comidas durante la semana de vacaciones de primavera (23 al 27 de marzo de 2020). Próximamente recibirá más información sobre dónde y cuándo puede acceder a las comidas después de la semana de vacaciones de primavera.

Proporcionaremos información a nuestras familias para acceder a recursos importantes. Sabemos que nuestras familias tendrán dificultades con el cierre de escuelas y otros negocios y es posible que necesiten acceder a la ayuda rápidamente. Le mantendremos informado de varias formas de acceder a los servicios de apoyo necesarios. Mientras tanto, visite 211info.org sí tiene necesidades inmediatas.

Revisaremos opciones de oportunidades de aprendizaje remoto o suplementario para nuestros estudiantes. Si bien no podemos garantizar en este momento que podamos proporcionar este tipo de aprendizaje durante el cierre, queremos informarle que estamos investigando activamente formas para que nuestros estudiantes se mantengan comprometidos. Seguiremos manteniéndolo informado. Mientras tanto, le enviaremos enlaces de recursos educativos que puede utilizar para trabajar activamente con sus hijos mientras están en casa. Esta información estará disponible mañana.

Seguiremos pidiendo a nuestros estudiantes, familias y personal que comprendan la importancia de esta emergencia nacional de salud mediante la práctica de medidas de distanciamiento social de no reunirse con más de 10 personas, lavarse las manos constantemente, evitar a las personas enfermas y cubrirse al toser o estornudar. Se le pide a todo el personal que figura como esencial y que trabaja en nuestras escuelas u oficinas para apoyar las funciones necesarias que se quede en casa si están enfermos, si está en una categoría de riesgo o tiene un miembro de su hogar en una categoría de riesgo.

div.p: Continuaremos manteniéndolo actualizado a medida que tengamos más información. Al hacer nuestra parte, podemos superar estos tiempos difíciles. Agradecemos su paciencia, amabilidad y compasión en los próximos días. Recuerde ... ¡Juntos somos Reynolds!

Reynolds School District will be offering meals for all students and families 18 and under at our three middle schools (H.B. Lee, Reynolds Middle, and Walt Morey) and at Reynolds High School during the week of March 16-20. Meals will be distributed Monday-Friday from 11:30am to 1:00pm. Meals will be provided for curbside pick-up (in cars or on foot) at each location. Signage will be posted directing you where to pick up.

p.strong: Servicio de comidas del 16 al 20 de marzo

div.p: Durante la semana del 16 al 20 de marzo, Reynolds School District ofrecerá comidas para todos los estudiantes en las tres escuelas secundarias (H.B. Lee, Reynolds Middle y Walt Morey) y también en Reynolds High School. Las comidas serán entregadas de lunes a viernes de 11:30 a.m. a 1 p.m. para llevar a su hogar. Puede retirarla desde la acera de la escuela. Puede ir a pie o en automóvil. En cada una de las escuelas habrá señales indicando el lugar exacto dónde recogerla.

Due to updated state guidance received on March 12, all Reynolds School District schools will now be closed March 16 through 31, with students returning on April 1. The district office and all school buildings will be closed during that time, and all conferences are canceled. We are currently planning efforts to offer meals to students during the closure and will be in touch with more information.

p.strong: Cambio en la fecha de cierre de las escuelas

div.p: Debido a la nueva dirección estatal recibida el día 12 de marzo, todas las escuelas de Reynolds School District estarán cerradas desde el 16 al 31 de marzo. Los estudiantes regresarán el 1 de abril. La oficina del distrito y todos los edificios escolares estarán cerrados durante ese tiempo, y todas las conferencias están canceladas. Actualmente estamos haciendo planes para ofrecer comidas a los estudiantes durante el cierre y nos pondremos en contacto con más información.

p.strong: Keeping You Informed - School Closure Starting March 16

div.p: Reynolds School District would like to thank our community of families, educators, and support staff for the concern and care you have shown during the rapidly changing circumstances around the novel coronavirus COVID-19. As a district, we remain committed to providing safe and healthy spaces for our students, families, and staff, who are always at the heart of any decision made by the board and district leadership.

In light of the speed with which COVID-19 is spreading and the risks our families and staff may be facing, we are taking the precautionary measure of closing schools for the week of March 16-20, 2020, and schools will remain closed the week of Spring Break March 23-27, 2020. All conferences for next week are canceled. During this two-week break, we will have the opportunity to clean our schools and prepare for students and staff to return at the earliest on March 30, 2020. This return date may change depending on guidance from the state.

We understand this difficult decision can be a hardship on many of our families. We will continue to coordinate services to help ensure our students have nutritious meals during this break. We will keep you informed as to where and when your student can access these services.

We encourage our students to remain engaged during this time! Our middle and high school students have take-home devices which can allow them to extend their learning while on break. We also encourage parents of our elementary students to enjoy time reading with their students.

We look forward to seeing you back at school on Monday, March 30, 2020 at the regularly scheduled late-start time. In the event there is any change to this date, we will continue to communicate by email, phone, push notification through Remind app, and post information on our websites.
We appreciate your patience as we all work together to ensure the safety of our students, families and staff! Together… We are Reynolds!

Reynolds School District desea agradecer a nuestra comunidad de familias, educadores y personal de apoyo por la preocupación y la atención que ha demostrado durante las circunstancias que cambian tan rápidamente con respecto al nuevo coronavirus COVID-19. Como distrito, seguimos comprometidos en proporcionar espacios seguros y saludables para nuestros estudiantes, familias y personal, quienes siempre están en el centro de cualquier decisión que toma la Junta Directiva y el liderazgo del distrito.

A la luz de la velocidad con la que se está extendiendo COVID-19 y los riesgos que nuestras familias y el personal pueden enfrentar, estamos tomando la medida de precaución de cerrar las escuelas durante la semana del 16 al 20 de marzo de 2020, y las escuelas permanecerán cerradas la semana de las vacaciones de primavera del 23 al 27 de marzo de 2020. Se cancelan todas las conferencias de la próxima semana. Durante este descanso de dos semanas, tendremos la oportunidad de limpiar nuestras escuelas y prepararnos para el regreso de los estudiantes y del personal que será no antes del 30 de marzo de 2020. Esta fecha de regreso puede cambiar dependiendo de la guía que recibamos del estado.

Entendemos que esta difícil decisión puede ser crear dificultad para muchas de nuestras familias. Continuaremos coordinando servicios para ayudar a asegurar que nuestros estudiantes tengan comidas nutritivas durante este descanso. Le mantendremos informado sobre dónde y cuándo su estudiante puede acceder a estos servicios.

¡Alentamos a nuestros estudiantes a permanecer comprometidos durante este tiempo! Nuestros estudiantes de secundaria y preparatoria tienen dispositivos para llevar a casa que les permiten extender su aprendizaje durante el descanso. También alentamos a los padres de nuestros alumnos de primaria a disfrutar el tiempo leyendo con sus alumnos.

Esperamos verlos de regreso en la escuela el lunes 30 de marzo de 2020 a la hora programada de inicio más tarde. En caso de que haya algún cambio en esta fecha, continuaremos comunicándonos por correo electrónico, teléfono, notificación automática a través de la aplicación Remind y publicaremos información en nuestros sitios web.
¡Agradecemos su paciencia mientras todos trabajamos juntos para garantizar la seguridad de nuestros estudiantes, familias y personal! Juntos ... ¡Somos Reynolds!
Dear Reynolds School District Families,

With the number of confirmed COVID-19 coronavirus cases in Oregon increasing, including the first instance in Multnomah County, Governor Brown announced new guidance tonight regarding group gatherings and social distancing. We remain committed to keeping our schools open and safe. In accordance with this evening’s guidance and in order to minimize potential opportunities for the virus to spread, we have decided to proactively begin suspending events that bring large groups of students, adults, and community members together.

Suspension of non-essential school-based activities begins immediately, effective Thursday, March 12, and will remain in effect for 30 days. This includes the suspension of all school-based assemblies and events, off-campus field trips, and events. With regard to athletics, we are following new state guidance denying audience admission at all school-based events, with the exception of essential personnel and credentialed media. The list of affected activities will grow as we work with partners and stakeholders over the coming days. We will update you as we make those decisions.
To be clear, we are taking every step possible so that we can continue to provide high-quality education for all of our students and keep our schools open.

We realize that this decision will impact every school community, and we know that many of the events, student performances, and other gatherings that we are suspending are those that schools, students, and families look forward to all year long. Suspending these events is consistent with guidance from health authorities, and we believe it is a prudent and responsible step to take at this time. We will be working with trip planners, event organizers, and others who are responsible for the affected activities. In cases when we are mandated to offer access to community members (e.g., Board of Education meetings), we hope to offer continued online streaming and are currently exploring other alternatives, including virtual meeting platforms, in order to continue the district’s governance and business.

The safety, health, and well-being of our students and staff is our highest priority. We will continue to work in close partnership with public health authorities to minimize both the spread of coronavirus and disruption to schools and students. We will continue emphasizing the importance of handwashing at school. Our custodians will continue to prioritize high-touch surfaces in classrooms and common areas. And we are making sure schools have adequate cleaning supplies.

Students, families, and everyone in our community can best support our efforts by washing hands frequently, covering mouths when coughing or sneezing, and using hand sanitizer. Those experiencing symptoms of the cold or flu should stay at home, only returning to school or work when symptom-free for 24 hours. If you are concerned about symptoms, please consult with a doctor.

Finally, you can find district messages about COVID-19 coronavirus, resources, links to public health agencies and a question/comment form by visiting https://www.reynolds.k12.or.us/district/coronavirus-covid-19.

Thank you for your cooperation and understanding during this difficult time. We will continue to rely on the guidance from Oregon public health authorities, the Department of Education, and the Office of the Governor. Please know that this message and the decisions being made at this time are being done in collaboration with many of the State of Oregon’s largest school districts, including the Beaverton School District, Eugene School District, Hillsboro School District, Portland Public Schools, and Salem-Keizer Public Schools. We appreciate their partnership at this time. We all collectively share the utmost concern for the health and safety of our students, employees, and communities.
Reynolds School District

Con el aumento en el número de casos confirmados de coronavirus COVID-19 en Oregón, incluyendo el primer caso confirmado en el condado de Multnomah, la gobernadora Brown anunció esta noche una nueva recomendación con respecto a las reuniones grupales y el distanciamiento social. Seguimos comprometidos a mantener nuestras escuelas abiertas y seguras. De acuerdo con la recomendación de esta noche y para minimizar las posibles oportunidades de propagación del virus, hemos decidido comenzar proactivamente a suspender los eventos que reúnen a grandes grupos de estudiantes, adultos y miembros de la comunidad.

La suspensión de actividades escolares no esenciales comienza de manera inmediata, a partir del jueves 12 de marzo, y permanecerá vigente durante los siguientes 30 días. Esto incluye la suspensión de todas las asambleas y eventos escolares, excursiones fuera de la escuela y reuniones y eventos de desarrollo profesional. Con respecto a los eventos deportivos, estamos siguiendo una nueva recomendación estatal que prohíbe la admisión de la audiencia en todos los eventos escolares, con la excepción del personal esencial y los medios de comunicación acreditados. La lista de actividades afectadas crecerá a medida que trabajamos con otras organizaciones y partes interesadas en los próximos días. Los actualizaremos a medida que tomemos esas decisiones.

Para ser claros, estamos tomando todas las medidas posibles para poder continuar brindando educación de alta calidad a todos nuestros estudiantes y mantener nuestras escuelas abiertas.
Sabemos que esta decisión afectará a todas las comunidades escolares, y sabemos que muchos de los eventos, conciertos estudiantiles y otras reuniones que estamos suspendiendo en las escuelas, son celebraciones que los estudiantes y las familias esperan durante todo el año. Suspender estos eventos es coherente con la recomendación de las autoridades de salud, y creemos que es un paso prudente y responsable en este momento. Trabajaremos con los organizadores de eventos y otras personas responsables de las actividades afectadas. En casos en los que tengamos que ofrecer obligatoriamente acceso a miembros de la comunidad (por ejemplo, reuniones de la Junta Directiva de Educación), esperamos ofrecer una transmisión continua en línea. Actualmente estamos explorando otras alternativas, que incluyen plataformas de reuniones virtuales para continuar con los asuntos y negocios del distrito.

La seguridad, la salud y el bienestar de nuestros estudiantes y personal son nuestra máxima prioridad. Continuaremos trabajando en estrecha colaboración con las autoridades de salud pública para minimizar tanto la propagación del coronavirus como la interrupción en las escuelas o para los estudiantes. Continuaremos enfatizando la importancia del lavado de manos en la escuela. Nuestros conserjes continuarán priorizando las superficies de alto contacto en los salones de clase y áreas comunes. Igualmente continuaremos suministrando a las escuelas con los materiales de limpieza adecuados.

Los estudiantes, las familias y todos en nuestra comunidad pueden apoyar nuestros esfuerzos lavándose las manos con frecuencia, cubriéndose la boca al toser o estornudar, y usando desinfectante para manos. Aquellos que experimenten síntomas de resfriado o gripe deben quedarse en casa, y solo regresar a la escuela o al trabajo si no han tenido síntomas por 24 horas. Si le preocupan los síntomas, consulte con un médico. Finalmente, puede encontrar mensajes del distrito sobre el coronavirus COVID-19, recursos, enlaces a agencias de salud pública y un formulario de preguntas / comentarios visitando la
página web https://www.reynolds.k12.or.us/district/coronavirus-covid-19.

Gracias por su cooperación y comprensión durante este difícil momento. Continuaremos confiando en las recomendaciones de las autoridades de salud pública de Oregon, el Departamento de Educación y la Oficina de la Gobernadora. Tenga en cuenta que este mensaje y las decisiones que se toman en este momento son tomadas en colaboración con muchos de los distritos escolares más grandes del estado de Oregon, incluidos los distritos escolares de Beaverton, Eugene, Hillsboro, Portland y Salem-Keizer. Agradecemos su colaboración en este momento. Compartimos colectivamente la preocupación por la salud y la seguridad de nuestros estudiantes y comunidades.
Reynolds School District

Dear Reynolds School District parents and guardians,

On Sunday, the Oregon Health Authority and Oregon Department of Education announced guidance for responding to COVID-19 cases in Oregon schools. Following is part of the announcement; you can read the guidance in full by clicking HERE.

p.em: At this time, the guidance recommends against closing schools and campuses where no cases of COVID-19 are present. It also recommends that schools, colleges and universities consider all alternatives before closing a school, college or university in the event that a COVID-19 case is detected among students or staff. The guidance identifies important strategies educational administrators can use to reduce the risk of COVID-19 within a school community and protect students from lost instructional time.

The guidance recognizes that the instruction schools and universities provide is vital to student well-being. In addition, schools provide many students their only ready access to health care and food. More than 22,000 students in Oregon experienced some form of homelessness in 2019.

The recommendation gives schools tools to prevent COVID-19 transmission and maintain a normal learning environment for students and staff. Under existing OHA guidance, individuals who have COVID-19, including students and educators, will be subject to self-isolation to prevent others from becoming infected.

div.p: The safety, health, and well-being of our students and staff is our highest priority. We will continue to work in close partnership with the Oregon Health Authority and Multnomah County Health, and follow their guidance in order to minimize both the spread of coronavirus and disruption to schools and students. We will continue emphasizing the importance of handwashing at school. Our custodians are now in week two of giving priority to wiping down high-touch surfaces in classrooms and common areas. And we have begun delivering extra supplies such as disinfecting wipes to schools and will continue to deliver supplies to all schools this week.

Finally, a reminder that you can best support these efforts by washing hands frequently, covering mouths when coughing or sneezing, and using hand sanitizer. Those experiencing symptoms of the cold or flu should stay at home, only returning to school or work when symptom-free for 24 hours. If you are concerned about symptoms, please consult with a doctor.

Dear Reynolds School District parents and guardians,

As the number of cases of the coronavirus COVID-19 continue to increase in the US, Reynolds School District is actively monitoring the situation and taking proactive steps to minimize risk in our schools.

The safety, health, and well-being of our students, families, and staff is our highest priority. We are working in partnership with surrounding school districts, Multnomah Education Service District (MESD), the Multnomah County Health Department (MCHD), Oregon Health Authority (OHA), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and other agencies closely involved with coronavirus spread. Daily update calls are being held by various agencies and attended by key staff in the District Office to stay informed of the latest news and recommendations.
As we work to keep you as informed as possible, we have received numerous inquiries at the District Office which are answered below that we hope will prove helpful:

p.strong: What is Reynolds doing to help stop the spread of viruses in the schools and other buildings?

div.p: Reynolds School District Facilities and Custodial teams are taking a number of preventative precautions to help stop the spread of COVID-19 and other viruses. These include:

ul.li: Enhanced daily cleaning of horizontal surfaces, door handles, and other high-touch areas susceptible to virus transmission with approved cleaners following CDC and MCHD guidelines.
Approved disinfecting wipes claiming to kill human coronavirus have been deployed to schools for staff to use throughout the day.
Hand sanitizer stations have been delivered and are being deployed/installed this week and next in all classrooms.
Additional staffing resources for daily cleaning are being deployed as needed to ensure night custodial has adequate staffing for sanitizing spaces.
Third-party cleaning services are on-call as needed for deeper cleaning requirements.

p.strong: When should a student or staff member stay home?

div.p: We are advising students and staff members to stay home if experiencing cold or flu symptoms. These measures are important to keep any possible COVID-19 cases from spreading, if applicable, and to also protect anyone who already has a dampened immune system from contracting COVID-19. If symptoms persist, please see your primary care provider.

p.strong: When should a student return to school if they have cold or flu symptoms?

div.p: If a student is experiencing cold or flu symptoms, please do not return to school until fever or cough has subsided for a full 24 hours without the use of medicine.

p.strong: When should a student or staff member be excluded or asked to go home from school or work?

div.p: Students and staff should follow the same exclusion guidelines outlined by the Multnomah County Health Department. These include the following:

ul.li: FEVER: Any fever greater than 100.4F. May return after 24 hours when temperature decreases without use of fever-reducing medicine.

COUGH: Persistent cough with or without fever, serious sustained coughing, shortness of breath, or difficulty breathing, or complaints that prevent the student from active participation in usual school activities, or student requiring more care than the school staff can safely provide.
VOMITING: At least 1 episode that is unexplained in the past 24 hours. May return when resolved for 24 hours.
DIARRHEA: Three or more watery or loose stools in 24 hours OR sudden onset of loose stools. May return when resolved for 24 hours.
STIFF NECK: or headache with accompanying fever. May return after resolution of symptoms or diagnosis made and clearance given.

RASH/SKIN LESION: Any new rash if not previously diagnosed by a health care provider OR if rash is increasing in size OR if new sores/wounds are developing day-to-day OR if rash, sores or wounds are draining and cannot be completely covered with a bandage.
JAUNDICE: Yellowing of eyes or skin. May return after diagnosis from physician and clearance given.
BEHAVIOR CHANGE: Such as new onset of irritability, lethargy or somnolence. May return after diagnosis from physician and clearance given.

p.strong: What can I do to help reduce the risk of getting COVID-19?

ul.li: You can help to reduce the risk of getting and spreading viral respiratory illnesses including coronavirus, the flu, and common cold by using and encouraging the following simple steps:
Wash your hands often with warm water and soap.
Cover your mouth with a tissue, sleeve, or elbow (not hands) when you cough or sneeze, and then wash your hands.
If you or someone in your household is sick, stay home and follow the guidance of your healthcare provider.
Keep your immune system strong by eating a healthy diet, getting enough sleep and regular exercise, and by taking care of underlying health conditions.

p.strong: How can I help myself and others to understand fear and hostility around the spread of COVID-19?

div.p: Misinformation about coronavirus can create fear and anxiety which can lead to stigma when people assume a group of people are more likely to get and spread a disease. We have heard reports from other districts that some students are being targeted and discriminated against in connection to coronavirus.

Reynolds School District is committed to equity and social justice while providing safe and inclusive schools where every student can learn. We do not tolerate hate speech or acts of discrimination. This becomes significantly important at a time when fears of a virus can easily foster suspicion without regard to fact.
Remember… VIRUSES DON’T DISCRIMINATE! Make sure you stay informed and report any type of discriminatory behavior to the District Office immediately.
Watch this video for more information: https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=24&v=jePXCdb5jmU&feature=emb_logo
More information and ongoing updates from public health officials are available online, including:

ul.li:
Multnomah County Health Department:
https://multco.us/health-officer/novel-coronavirus-covid-19

Oregon Health Authority (OHA):

Centers for Disease Control (CDC):
https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/index.html

Oregon Department of Education (ODE) Communicable Disease Guidance:
https://www.oregon.gov/ode/students-and-family/healthsafety/Documents/commdisease.pdf

div.p: Thank you,
Dr. Danna Diaz, Superintendent of Schools
Reynolds School District

Dear Reynolds School District parents and guardians,
We have received questions or concerns from our community about news of the novel coronavirus (respiratory illness) called COVID-19. Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses that usually cause mild respiratory illnesses such as the common cold. COVID-19 is a new coronavirus that had not been seen in humans before.
Oregon announced its first presumptive case of COVID-19, on February 28, 2020. The patient was an adult who spent time in a school in the Lake Oswego school district and may have exposed students and staff at the school. The individual has been isolated and is being cared for at a local hospital. OHA epidemiologists are working closely with public health investigators at Washington County Department of Health and Human Services to identify close contacts of the case.
The health department proactively contacts household members of cases of COVID-19 and will request that they self-isolate, meaning not attend school or work, for 14 days after their last contact with the infectious person. In the event that a classroom of individuals is exposed to a student, teacher, or other staff with confirmed COVID-19, Multnomah County Health Department will likely exclude the entire classroom for 14 days after the last exposure.
The district is closely monitoring this situation and is in frequent contact with public health authorities. Public health officials advise parents to keep students home if they display any signs of illness. Health officials also support schools in sending home or keeping home students and staff members who appear unwell, consistent with the tri-county standard exclusion guidelines.
Tri-County Exclusion Guidelines: https://www.co.washington.or.us/HHS/CommunicableDiseases/upload/Disease_Exclusion_Guide_Updated-July-2017-1.pdf
The internal team actively reviewing coronavirus developments includes the Superintendent, our principals, and staff from Communications, Emergency Management, Student Health, and Facilities. We will continue to work with the health department to determine when and if any additional measures, including decisions about cleaning, school closures, and social distancing need to be taken.
You can help yourself and your student(s) to reduce their risk for getting and spreading viral respiratory infections, including the flu and the common cold, by encouraging them to take simple steps which will also prevent COVID-19:

ul.li: Wash your hands often with warm water and soap.
Cover your mouth with a tissue, sleeve, or elbow (not hands) when you cough or sneeze, and then wash your hands.
If you or someone in your household is sick, stay home and follow the guidance of your healthcare provider.
Keep your immune system strong by eating a healthy diet, getting enough sleep and regular exercise, and by taking care of underlying health conditions.

br.strong: There are also basic steps every household should take to prepare for any unexpected event:

ul.li: Learn about your employer’s sick leave and telecommuting policies.
Establish a childcare plan in the event your kids need to stay home from school.
Make sure you have the kinds of foods, drinks, medications and pet supplies you would want if you needed to stay home and limit your contact with other people for a couple weeks.
Get to know your neighbors, especially those who might need extra help like seniors or people living alone.
In the face of rumors check https://multco.us/health-officer/novel-coronavirus-covid-19 for reliable information.

p.br: More information and ongoing updates from public health officials are available online, including:

Oregon Health Authority (OHA): https://www.oregon.gov/oha/PH/DISEASESCONDITIONS/DISEASESAZ/Pages/emerging-respiratory-infections.aspx

This is to keep you informed regarding the recent report of a case of novel coronavirus COVID-19 with an individual who resides in Washington County and is an employee with Lake Oswego School District.

The health and safety of our students, staff, and families is our highest priority. Reynolds School District is closely monitoring this situation and is in frequent contact with public health authorities. The internal team actively reviewing coronavirus developments includes the Superintendent, our principals, and staff from Communications, Emergency Management, Student and Family Services, and Operations. We have been assured by public health officials that they believe current risk is minimal and currently advise that schools do not need to take any special precautions beyond those normally recommended to prevent the spread of viruses.

We will be sharing more information with you tomorrow afternoon (Sunday, March 1, 2020) including what to look for if your child or a family member is ill and when to keep your child home from school if showing symptoms of illness. In the meantime, you can follow all of the progress of the virus in Oregon and other areas and get prevention information by visiting https://multco.us/health-officer/novel-coronavirus-covid-19

p.em: Please see below for information from Multnomah Education Service District (MESD) and Multnomah County Health Department regarding the coronavirus. While we do not believe that the Reynolds community is at risk at this time, we wanted to share information and resources with you. The health and safety of our students and staff is our highest priority, and we will continue to follow the situation closely.

div.p: An outbreak of a new virus called the novel coronavirus, or 2019-nCoV, that began in Wuhan City, China, has created concern and questions recently. MESD is working closely with Multnomah County Health Department to assess any risk for local schools.

At this time, we believe the risk to the general Multnomah County population is low. The Health Department is monitoring the situation closely and has created a general information sheet about this virus. It is included here.

This is a new virus, and health recommendations may change as public health experts learn more about the disease. At this time, people who have recently visited China do not need to stay at home unless they are sick. People who have visited an area with confirmed cases of the virus should watch for a fever, cough, and trouble breathing for 14 days after return. If they get sick, they should stay home and call their health care provider.

At this time there is no vaccine to prevent the new coronavirus. But this is a good reminder to everyone that it is still flu season. We want to remind people to make sure they have their flu shot, and to stay home if they are sick.

If you have questions about this new coronavirus that aren’t answered by the FAQ, please visit the Multnomah County Health Dept website at multco.us/health-officer/novel-coronavirus-2019. You can also call Communicable Disease Services during normal business hours at 503-988-3406, or call your school nurse.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jennifer Vines, Health Officer
Multnomah County Health Department

p.em: A continuación encontrará la información del Distrito de Servicios Educativos del condado de Multnomah y el Departamento de Salud del Condado de Multnomah con respecto al coronavirus. Aunque no creemos que la comunidad de Reynolds esté en riesgo en este momento, deseábamos compartir información y recursos con usted. La salud y seguridad de nuestros estudiantes y personal es nuestra máxima prioridad, y continuaremos siguiendo de cerca la situación.

hr.p: Recientemente un brote de un nuevo virus llamado nuevo coronavirus, o 2019-nCoV, que comenzó en la ciudad de Wuhan, China, ha creado preocupación y preguntas. MESD está trabajando estrechamente con el Departamento de Salud del Condado de Multnomah para evaluar cualquier riesgo para las escuelas locales.

En este momento, creemos que el riesgo para la población general del Condado de Multnomah es bajo. El Departamento de Salud está monitoreando de cerca la situación y ha creado una hoja de información general sobre este virus. Esta información se incluye aquí.

Este es un virus nuevo y las recomendaciones de salud pueden cambiar a medida que los expertos en salud pública aprendan más sobre la enfermedad. En este momento, las personas que han visitado China recientemente no necesitan quedarse en casa a menos que estén enfermas. Las personas que han visitado un área con casos confirmados del virus deben estar atentos a fiebre, tos y problemas para respirar durante 14 días después del regreso. Si se enferman, deben quedarse en casa y llamar a su proveedor de atención médica.

En este momento no existe una vacuna para prevenir el nuevo coronavirus. Pero este es un buen recordatorio para todos de que todavía es temporada de gripe. Queremos recordarles a las personas que se aseguren de vacunarse contra la gripe y que se queden en casa si están enfermos.

Si tiene preguntas sobre este nuevo coronavirus que no aparecen en las preguntas frecuentes adjuntas, visite el sitio web del Departamento de Salud del Condado de Multnomah en el sitio web: multco.us/health-officer/novel-coronavirus-2019. También puede llamar a Servicios de Enfermedades Transmisibles durante el horario normal de atención al 503-988-3406, o llamar a la enfermera de su escuela.

Atentamente,
Dra. Jennifer Vines, Oficial de Salud Departamento de Salud del Condado de Multnomah
